categories: Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH) Screening

questions.text: Does the child wake up, startle, or show a change in facial expression when there is a loud noise?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormal findings in the questionnaire and physical examination (marked sections).
questions.actions: If judged as 'Detailed Evaluation Needed', there is a possibility of hearing loss. If there is no reaction to sound or the reaction is consistently absent, a visit to an ENT specialist is recommended.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that without a hearing test, hearing loss is typically discovered by guardians through observation around 30 months of age on average. Emphasize the importance of early diagnosis.
questions.pe_item: Microtia, Aural Atresia □ Present □ Absent / Visible Cleft Lip/Palate □ Present □ Absent □ Uncooperative
questions.pe_caution: If these conditions are present, hearing loss may occur accompanied by frequent otitis media or inner ear diseases, so regular check-ups every 6 months are necessary.

questions.text: Did the child undergo the Newborn Hearing Screening? (Within 1 month of expected due date for premature infants)
questions.criteria: Detailed evaluation is needed if the screening was not taken or if a re-test is required for even one ear.
questions.actions: If Newborn Hearing Screening was not performed, it must be done within 1 month of birth. If a re-test is required for even one ear, an ENT visit and ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response) test are needed within 3 months.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that hearing screening must be performed early in life, and missing this period may lead to language development delays.

questions.text: Were there any abnormal findings in the Newborn Hearing Screening?
questions.criteria: If there is a re-test result or abnormal findings in the hearing screening.
questions.actions: If there is a re-test judgment or abnormal finding, an ENT visit and detailed hearing test (ABR) must be performed within 3 months.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that early diagnosis of hearing is essential for normal language development and guide them to consult a specialist if there are hearing abnormalities.

questions.text: Does the child make various sounds (ah, woo, ee) or make sounds when laughing?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormal findings in the questionnaire and physical examination (marked sections).
questions.actions: If the child does not make sounds on their own, there is a possibility of hearing loss. A detailed hearing test at an ENT clinic is required.
questions.caregiver_note: Since hearing loss is difficult to detect early and is often found around 30 months of age, explain the necessity of early testing.
questions.pe_item: Microtia, Aural Atresia □ Present □ Absent / Visible Cleft Lip/Palate □ Present □ Absent □ Uncooperative
questions.pe_caution: If these conditions are present, otitis media or inner ear diseases may accompany them, so regular check-ups every 6 months are necessary.

questions.text: Has the child been hospitalized in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) for more than 5 days after birth?
questions.criteria: If there is a history of NICU admission for more than 5 days.
questions.actions: A history of NICU treatment is considered a risk factor for hearing loss. A detailed hearing test (ABR) is recommended before 6 months of age.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that premature infants or children with intensive care experience are a high-risk group for congenital hearing loss.

questions.text: Did the child undergo a hearing screening (hearing test) within 1 month after birth? (Within 1 month of expected due date for premature infants)
questions.criteria: If the test was not performed, or if there is a re-test/abnormal finding in at least one ear.
questions.actions: If screening was not performed, a detailed hearing test (ABR) is recommended within 3 months.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that it is important to receive a hearing test within 1 month of birth, and warn of the risk of language development delay if not performed.

questions.text: Did you receive a 're-test' judgment for one or both ears in the Newborn Hearing Screening?
questions.criteria: If re-test judgment received, ENT treatment needed within 3 months.
questions.actions: If re-test judgment received, detailed examination (ABR) and follow-up observation are recommended.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that even if the re-test result is good, hearing tests should be performed again if language development is delayed later.

questions.text: Has the child ever been diagnosed with 'hearing loss' in one or both ears?
questions.criteria: If there is a history of hearing loss diagnosis.
questions.actions: If diagnosed with hearing loss, regular check-ups every 6 months, hearing aid use, and rehabilitation therapy are recommended.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that children with hearing loss are at risk of language development delay, so early rehabilitation is necessary.

questions.text: Has the child been hospitalized in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) for more than 5 days after birth?
questions.criteria: NICU admission for more than 5 days is a risk factor for hearing loss.
questions.actions: If there are risk factors for hearing loss, detailed hearing tests are recommended every 6 months.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that regular check-ups are important because early detection of hearing loss is difficult.
questions.pe_item: Ear Physical Exam □ Abnormal Findings □ No Abnormal Findings □ Uncooperative
questions.pe_caution: Hearing loss is possible if accompanied by microtia, aural atresia, or cleft lip/palate.

questions.text: Is there anyone in the family (parents or relatives) who has had hearing loss since childhood?
questions.criteria: If part of a high-risk group for hereditary hearing loss.
questions.actions: Follow-up tests every 6 months are necessary if there is a family history of hereditary hearing loss.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain the possibility of hereditary hearing loss and recommend regular ENT check-ups.

questions.text: Has the child ever been diagnosed with 'hearing loss' in one or both ears?
questions.criteria: If there is a history of hearing loss diagnosis.
questions.actions: Regular hearing tests and concurrent rehabilitation therapy are necessary.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain the necessity of continuous follow-up observation after a hearing loss diagnosis.

questions.text: Is the child wearing a hearing aid or cochlear implant in one or both ears?
questions.criteria: If wearing a hearing aid or cochlear implant.
questions.actions: Check the wearing status and perform periodic hearing tests.
questions.caregiver_note: Guide on device management and the importance of regular check-ups.

questions.text: Has the child been hospitalized in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) for more than 5 days after birth?
questions.criteria: High-risk group if NICU admission > 5 days.
questions.actions: Hearing tests every 6 months are needed to check for hearing loss.
questions.caregiver_note: Inform about the possibility of hearing loss and explain the importance of early testing.
questions.pe_item: Ear Physical Exam □ Abnormal Findings □ No Abnormal Findings □ Uncooperative
questions.pe_caution: Hearing tests are recommended if accompanied by ear structural abnormalities or cleft lip/palate.

questions.text: Is there anyone in the family (parents or relatives) who has had hearing loss since childhood?
questions.criteria: If there is a family history of hereditary hearing loss.
questions.actions: Regular follow-up tests recommended; refer to a specialist if genetic counseling is needed.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain the necessity of early hearing tests if there is a family history.

questions.text: Has the child suffered from acute otitis media (ear pain, fever, etc.) multiple times? (More than 4 times in 6 months, or more than 6 times in 1 year)
questions.criteria: If there is a history of recurrent otitis media.
questions.actions: Continuous infection is a risk factor for hearing loss; specialist treatment is required.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that recurrent otitis media increases the risk of hearing loss.

questions.text: Has the child ever been diagnosed with 'hearing loss' in one or both ears?
questions.criteria: If there is a history of hearing loss diagnosis.
questions.actions: Regular tests are needed to check for progression of hearing loss.
questions.caregiver_note: Emphasize the necessity of early hearing re-evaluation.

questions.text: Is the child wearing a hearing aid or cochlear implant in one or both ears?
questions.criteria: If currently wearing a device.
questions.actions: Check hearing aid/cochlear implant status and perform concurrent rehabilitation therapy.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain the importance of hearing assist device management.

questions.text: Has the child been hospitalized in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) for more than 5 days after birth?
questions.criteria: High-risk group if NICU admission > 5 days.
questions.actions: Tests are needed every 6 months due to high risk of hearing loss.
questions.caregiver_note: Guide on the necessity of early diagnosis and regular follow-up tests.

questions.actions: Management of hearing aid/cochlear implant and regular hearing tests are necessary.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain the importance of regular tests and the impact on language development.

questions.text: Has the child suffered from acute otitis media (ear pain, fever, etc.) multiple times? (More than 4 times in 6 months, or more than 6 times in 1 year)
questions.criteria: If there is a history of recurrent otitis media.
questions.actions: High possibility of hearing loss with recurrent infections; ENT visit required.
questions.caregiver_note: Education on management to prevent recurrence of otitis media.

questions.text: Did the child undergo a dental examination?
questions.actions: Dental examinations help check health conditions related to oral and hearing health.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain the need to manage oral health together with hearing.

questions.text: Did the child correctly point to and match all pictures during the dental examination (screening)?
questions.criteria: Picture recognition/reaction is normal for normal hearing.
questions.actions: Consider possibility of hearing loss if reaction is slow or inaccurate.
questions.caregiver_note: Guide on the importance of evaluating visual-auditory coordination skills.

questions.text: Has the child been hospitalized in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) for more than 5 days after birth?
questions.criteria: Hearing loss risk group if NICU admission > 5 days.
questions.actions: Regular hearing tests and language development evaluation required.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that without a hearing test, hearing loss is typically discovered after 30 months of age on average.

questions.pe_caution: Hearing loss is possible if microtia, aural atresia, or cleft lip/palate exists.

questions.actions: Detailed hearing test recommended if there is a possibility of hereditary hearing loss.
questions.caregiver_note: Emphasize the necessity of early hearing tests if there is a family history.

questions.actions: Regular hearing tests and hearing aid management required.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that hearing loss can affect language and cognitive development.

questions.text: Does the child have trouble hearing or problems with hearing?
questions.criteria: If hearing loss is suspected by guardian observation.
questions.actions: Hearing test via ENT visit is required.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain the importance of detecting hearing changes through guardian observation.

questions.actions: Check device operation status and periodic check-ups are needed.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain the importance of device management.

questions.text: Did the child undergo a hearing test (Pure Tone Audiometry) for kindergarten/elementary school life?
questions.criteria: Early evaluation needed if hearing test not performed.
questions.actions: Hearing test recommended before entering elementary school.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain the importance of the test for school adaptation and learning.

questions.text: Has the child been hospitalized in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) for more than 5 days after birth?
questions.criteria: High-risk group if NICU admission experience > 5 days.
questions.actions: Detailed hearing test needed every 6 months as a high-risk group for hearing loss.
questions.caregiver_note: Guide on importance of early detection and follow-up tests.
