questions.actions: Regular check of hearing aid/cochlear implant and concurrent speech therapy required.
questions.caregiver_note: Emphasize importance of checking device operation and maintenance.

questions.text: Did the child undergo a hearing test (Pure Tone Audiometry) for kindergarten/elementary school life?
questions.criteria: Early evaluation needed if hearing test not performed.
questions.actions: Pure Tone Audiometry recommended before school adaptation.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that it is a necessary test for school life adaptation and language development.

questions.text: Do you ever kiss the baby directly on the lips?
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution Needed
questions.actions: Kissing the baby directly on the lips poses a risk of infection. Since neonates are particularly susceptible to viral or bacterial infections, avoid direct contact and express affection in other ways.
questions.caregiver_note: Even if it is a simple expression of affection, kissing on the lips should be avoided when the baby's immune system is weak.

questions.text: Do you always wash your hands after changing the child's diaper?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Hygiene Education Needed
questions.actions: You must wash your hands after changing a diaper. Viruses in stool can be transmitted through hands, so the guardian's hygiene is also crucial.
questions.caregiver_note: Hand washing after diaper changes is the most basic and important habit for preventing the spread of germs.

questions.text: Do you always wash the child's hands after returning from an outing?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Guidance Needed
questions.actions: Infants have high exposure to infection when going out. Be sure to wash their hands with soap and water upon returning home.
questions.caregiver_note: Washing hands after outdoor activities is effective in preventing viral diseases.

questions.text: Does the child wash their hands with soap and water after returning from an outing?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Education Needed
questions.actions: Parents should practice together so that the child can develop the habit of washing hands on their own after going out.
questions.caregiver_note: Voluntary hand-washing habits are formed through repeated demonstration.

questions.text: Does the child always wash their hands with soap after bowel movements or urination?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Lifestyle Guidance Needed
questions.actions: During the toilet training period, you must also teach the habit of washing hands after using the toilet.
questions.caregiver_note: Hand washing after toileting is an important step in forming independent hygiene habits.

questions.text: Does the child cover their mouth with their hands when coughing or sneezing?
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution Needed, No = Good
questions.actions: Blocking a cough or sneeze with hands increases the risk of virus transmission. Instruct the child to cover their mouth with a tissue or their sleeve (elbow).
questions.caregiver_note: Cough etiquette requires repeated learning at home before entering elementary school.

questions.text: Do you teach the child to wash their hands after blowing their nose or covering it with their hands?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Education Needed
questions.actions: Secretions left on hands after blowing the nose can cause the spread of germs. Teach proper hand washing and tissue usage together.
questions.caregiver_note: Hand hygiene is a key factor in preventing respiratory infections.

questions.text: Has the newborn undergone the screening for congenital metabolic disorders (Newborn Screening)?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormal findings in the questionnaire and examination / Detailed Evaluation Needed: Any abnormality or blank response
questions.actions:
If judged as 'Detailed Evaluation Needed':
- 1. If not tested, recommend testing as soon as possible (verify place and time of birth).
- 2. If tested but result is unknown, verify the result.
- Explain that the Newborn Screening for metabolic disorders is a mandatory national screening for early detection and prognosis improvement.
questions.caregiver_note: Early detection of congenital metabolic disorders is crucial even if symptoms are not apparent in the neonatal period. Explain that this test is done via blood sampling shortly after birth, and the results must be checked.

questions.text: Did the newborn receive a 'Normal' (Negative or No Abnormality) result in the screening for congenital metabolic disorders?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormal findings in the questionnaire and examination / Detailed Evaluation Needed: Any abnormality or blank response
questions.actions:
If judged as 'Detailed Evaluation Needed':
- Additional testing is required if the result is 'Positive', 'Abnormal', or 'Re-test Needed'.
- If the result has not been received or is unknown, guide them to check with the public health center or obstetrics clinic.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that the metabolic screening is essential for the early diagnosis of metabolic disorders. Emphasize that the result must be checked, and immediate re-testing is necessary if there are any abnormalities.

questions.text: Which color most closely resembles the child's recent stool?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormal findings in the questionnaire and examination / Detailed Evaluation Needed: Selection of No. 3 (Pale/Gray/White) or blank
questions.actions:
If judged as 'Detailed Evaluation Needed':
- Pale, gray, or white stool suggests Biliary Atresia or hepatobiliary disease.
- Recommend visiting a Department of Pediatrics or a Gastroenterologist as soon as possible.
questions.caregiver_note: If pale/gray/white stool persists after 2 weeks of age, it may be pathological jaundice. Explain that early medical consultation is critical because failure to discharge bile normally can lead to liver damage.

questions.category: Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH) Screening
questions.text: Did the fetus remain in a breech position (legs pointing downward) until late pregnancy?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormal findings in the questionnaire and examination / Detailed Evaluation Needed: Abnormal findings or blank
questions.actions: Breech delivery is a major risk factor for DDH. If risk factors are present, referral to a pediatric orthopedic specialist is required.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that breech presentation increases the risk of hip dislocation, making confirmation during early check-ups important.

questions.category: Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH) Screening
questions.text: Was there a history of oligohydramnios (deficient amniotic fluid)?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormal findings in the questionnaire and examination / Detailed Evaluation Needed: Abnormal findings or blank
questions.actions: Oligohydramnios can restrict fetal movement, increasing the risk of DDH. Orthopedic evaluation is needed if risk factors are present.
questions.caregiver_note: DDH is easier to treat when detected early, so explain that screening is mandatory if risk factors exist.

questions.category: Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH) Screening
questions.text: Is there a family history (parents or siblings) of Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH)?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormal findings in the questionnaire and examination / Detailed Evaluation Needed: Abnormal findings or blank
questions.actions: A family history increases the likelihood of congenital hip dislocation. Orthopedic consultation and hip ultrasound are recommended.
questions.caregiver_note: Explain that the likelihood of occurrence is higher with a family history, so early ultrasound screening is recommended during this period.

questions.category: Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH) Screening
questions.text: Has the child ever undergone a hip ultrasound regarding Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH)?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormal findings in the questionnaire and examination / Detailed Evaluation Needed: Abnormal findings or blank
questions.actions:
If judged as 'Detailed Evaluation Needed':
- If hip ultrasound was not performed, explain the necessity and recommend referral to orthopedics.
- Check previous test results and whether follow-up testing is needed.
questions.caregiver_note: The prognosis for DDH is excellent if diagnosed and treated before 6 months of age. Explain the importance of early ultrasound to check for dislocation or instability.

questions.category: Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH) Screening
questions.text: Has the child ever been diagnosed with Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH)?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormal findings in the questionnaire and examination / Detailed Evaluation Needed: Abnormal findings or blank
questions.actions:
If judged as 'Detailed Evaluation Needed':
- Verify if the diagnosed child is currently maintaining treatment (wearing a brace, etc.).
- Recommend orthopedic re-evaluation if treatment has stopped or if there are abnormalities.
questions.caregiver_note: If diagnosed with DDH, explain that adherence to brace wear or treatment must be verified. Emphasize that missing the treatment window can affect walking development.

questions.text: Is the child exposed to electronic media (e.g., smartphones, tablets, TV)?
questions.actions: It is not recommended to expose children under 2 years of age to electronic media, including TVs, computers, smartphones, video games, handheld game consoles, and tablets. For children under 2, receiving positive stimulation through direct visual and tactile experiences and forming a secure attachment through active interaction with caregivers is paramount. Electronic media is detrimental to a developing child due to its passive nature, where content is received unilaterally. If exposure to electronic media is unavoidable, it must be viewed in the presence of a parent, and strict rules regarding location, time, and days of use must be established and adhered to. Even if exposed, the total daily screen time should not exceed 2 hours.

questions.text: Do parents use electronic media while being with the child?
questions.actions: Parents using electronic media while with their child provides an opportunity for indirect exposure (second-hand screen time). This is a critical period where the child needs to make eye contact and actively interact with parents. Adults with the child should actively respond to the child's sounds, expressions, and actions to build intimacy and attachment. There should be established rules for parental media use within the home. This serves as the starting point for guiding the child's future media usage habits. If adult media use is unavoidable in the child's presence, at least one adult should remain available for active interaction with the child. If parents are in a high-risk group for excessive media use, there is a high probability that the child will also fall into the high-risk group.

questions.text: Does a guardian view the media together with the child (co-viewing) when exposing them to electronic media?
questions.actions: While it is preferable not to expose children of this age to electronic media, if usage is necessary, a guardian must co-view the content. This allows the guardian to monitor and supervise the content exposed to the child and to explain or convey it in a form appropriate for the child.

questions.text: What is the child's average daily screen time (electronic media exposure time)?
questions.actions: Educate that it is desirable not to allow any electronic media exposure for children of this age. If there is exposure time, recommend reducing it.

questions.text: Do parents use electronic media (e.g., smartphones, TV, tablets) while being with the child?
questions.actions: Parents using electronic media while with their child provides an opportunity for indirect exposure. There should be established rules for parental media use within the home, which must be adhered to. This serves as the starting point for guiding the child's future media usage habits in a desirable direction.

questions.text: Do you check/monitor what the child is watching on electronic media?
questions.actions: If the child uses electronic media, the guardian must stay by the child's side to monitor the content. It is necessary to explain inappropriate content or correct the situation by observing the child's reactions. If the child appears frightened or their mood deteriorates during media exposure, usage should be stopped immediately.

questions.text: Are there rules regarding the location, days, and time of the child's electronic media use?
questions.actions: There must be rules regarding electronic media exposure within the home. Usage should be prohibited in sleeping areas, and viewing time should be limited to less than 2 hours per day.

questions.text: What is the child's average daily screen time?
questions.actions: Educate that it is desirable not to allow any electronic media exposure for children of this age. If there is exposure time, recommend reducing it.

questions.text: Are you aware of the content the child is watching on electronic media (e.g., smartphones, TV, tablets)?
questions.actions: If the child uses electronic media, the guardian must stay by the child's side to monitor the content. It is necessary to explain inappropriate content or correct the situation by observing the child's reactions. If the child appears frightened or their mood deteriorates during media exposure, usage should be stopped immediately.

questions.text: Are there rules for electronic media use?
questions.actions: There must be rules regarding electronic media exposure within the home. Specific details of the rules should be agreed upon by family members, and it is desirable to limit viewing time to less than 2 hours per day.

questions.text: Does the child follow the rules for electronic media use?
questions.actions: Encourage the child to exercise self-regulation while following the rules. In case of rule violations, immediate feedback should be provided, and it is recommended to stop usage.

questions.text: What is the child's average daily screen time?
questions.actions: Educate that appropriate electronic media exposure for children of this age is within 1 to 2 hours.

questions.text: Do you provide nighttime feeding (including both breastfeeding and bottle-feeding)?
questions.criteria: Yes = Abnormal, No = Good
questions.actions: Nighttime feeding increases the risk of dental caries and should be stopped as soon as possible. Feeding during sleep, in particular, allows sugars to remain in the mouth for extended periods, promoting bacterial proliferation.
questions.caregiver_note: Feeding while the child is asleep reduces saliva secretion, making teeth prone to decay. Establish a habit of wiping the inside of the mouth after feeding.

questions.text: Is the child practicing weaning off the bottle and drinking from a cup?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Oral Health Education Needed
questions.actions: After 18 months, encourage the habit of using a cup instead of a bottle. Prolonged bottle use can cause malocclusion, cavities in front teeth (nursing bottle caries), and delayed oral development.
questions.caregiver_note: Using a cup helps develop the muscles of the jaw, tongue, and lips. Start practicing slowly with a small cup.

questions.text: Are there any teeth suspected of having cavities, or teeth with abnormal color or shape?
questions.criteria: Yes = Detailed Evaluation Needed, No = Good
questions.actions: If the tooth color turns brown or gray, or if the surface appears rough, it may be an early sign of dental caries. A visit to a pediatric dentist is recommended.
questions.caregiver_note: Cavities can progress rapidly even without pain. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial.

questions.text: How many teeth have currently erupted (come out of the gums)?
questions.criteria: Less than 20 = Detailed Evaluation Needed
questions.actions: By 24 months, usually 16 to 20 primary teeth should have erupted. If tooth eruption is delayed or asymmetrical, recommend a consultation with a pediatric dentist.
questions.caregiver_note: Delayed tooth eruption can depend on nutritional status, genetics, and gum condition. Observe continuously and establish dental care habits.

questions.text: Do you brush the child's teeth at least twice a day?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Oral Health Education Needed
questions.actions: Instruct to brush teeth twice a day, morning and evening. Especially after brushing before bed, avoid consuming food or beverages.
questions.caregiver_note: Dental care habits are formed from early life. Guardians should brush together with the child and repeatedly teach the correct method.

questions.text: Are you practicing exclusive breastfeeding?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No/Partial = Education Needed
questions.actions: Breast milk strengthens the child's immunity and helps prevent diseases. Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended until 6 months of age, after which it is desirable to continue breastfeeding alongside complementary foods.
questions.caregiver_note: If not exclusively breastfeeding, explain the benefits of breast milk and encourage continued attempts.

questions.text: Nighttime feeding increases milk-producing hormones, thereby increasing milk supply. Are you breastfeeding at night?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Education Needed
questions.actions: Nighttime feeding promotes prolactin secretion, which is crucial for maintaining milk supply. Inform that skipping night feeds may reduce milk production.
questions.caregiver_note: Prolactin secretion is maintained at its highest levels during nighttime feeding, playing a key role in sustaining breastfeeding.

questions.text: Breastfeeding should be done on demand. Do you recognize the signs that your child is expressing hunger?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No/Don't Know = Education Needed
questions.actions: According to the WHO 'Ten Steps to Successful Breastfeeding', you should recognize hunger cues and breastfeed immediately.
questions.caregiver_note: You should recognize signs such as sucking on lips or hands, or turning the head (rooting reflex), and breastfeed immediately.

questions.text: Are you aware that frequent breastfeeding helps resolve problems like mastitis or breast engorgement?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No/Don't Know = Education Needed
questions.actions: Stopping breastfeeding during mastitis or engorgement can worsen the condition. Explain that it can be resolved with warm compresses, gentle massage, and regular breastfeeding.
questions.caregiver_note: Breastfeeding aids in recovery from inflammation, and it is recommended to encourage the baby to nurse from the affected area.

questions.text: Vitamin D may be insufficient for exclusively breastfed babies. Are you supplementing Vitamin D?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No/Don't Know = Nutrition Guidance Needed
questions.actions: Exclusively breastfed infants are at high risk of Vitamin D deficiency. Caution is especially needed for vegetarian mothers, those living in high latitudes, or those with limited outdoor activity. Supplementation of 400 IU of Vitamin D daily is recommended from birth.
questions.caregiver_note: Breastfed infants are prone to Vitamin D deficiency, which can affect bone formation during growth. It is desirable for both the mother and baby to take Vitamin D supplements.

questions.text: Are you aware that it is not necessary to disinfect the nipple area before breastfeeding?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No/Don't Know = Education Needed
questions.actions: Montgomery glands on the nipples secrete natural lubricants to protect them. Using disinfectants can dry out the nipples, increasing the risk of cracks or infection. Wiping gently with clean water before feeding is sufficient.
questions.caregiver_note: Sebaceous glands protect breast tissue, so separate disinfection is not required. Inform that excessive disinfection can cause mastitis.

questions.text: Are you aware that using a pacifier is not recommended during this period?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No/Don't Know = Education Needed
questions.actions: Pacifiers in the early postnatal period can cause nipple confusion. They should be avoided until the baby's latch-on reflex is well established.
questions.caregiver_note: Pacifiers can affect the baby's mouth shape and breastfeeding latch. They can be used limitedly if necessary after breastfeeding is well established.

questions.text: Have you ever stopped breastfeeding due to jaundice?
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution, No = Good
questions.actions: Physiological jaundice shortly after birth usually resolves naturally. Stopping breastfeeding can worsen jaundice, so continued breastfeeding is recommended. However, pathological jaundice (lasting more than 3 weeks or rising bilirubin levels) requires medical evaluation.
questions.caregiver_note: Most jaundice during breastfeeding is temporary. It is often due to insufficient intake or dehydration, so breastfeeding frequency should be increased.

questions.text: Are you aware that excessive consumption of nutritional supplements, herbal medicines, or health supplements by a breastfeeding mother can affect the child?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No/Don't Know = Caution Needed
questions.actions: Excessive intake of health supplements, herbal medicines, or specific nutrients during breastfeeding can affect the child through changes in breast milk composition. Guide them to consult a specialist before consumption if necessary.
questions.caregiver_note: Breast milk composition is directly affected by the mother's diet. In particular, ginseng, red ginseng, and medicinal herbs can cause excitability or sleep disturbances in the baby.

questions.text: Iron may be insufficient during the weaning period if exclusively breastfeeding. are you providing iron supplements or iron-rich complementary foods?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No/Don't Know = Nutrition Guidance Needed
questions.actions: Since the iron content of breast milk decreases after 4-6 months, iron intake is crucial during the weaning period. Start iron-supplemented foods after 6 months to prevent iron-deficiency anemia, and recommend pediatric consultation if necessary. The AAP recommends supplementing 1 mg/kg of iron starting from 4 months.
questions.caregiver_note: Breastfed babies deplete their iron stores from birth, increasing the risk of deficiency after 6 months. Iron-fortified weaning foods (rice porridge, beef, etc.) are recommended.

questions.text: Are you aware that breastfeeding can be continued alongside solid foods or child meals until after 24 months of age?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Education Needed
questions.actions: WHO and UNICEF recommend exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months, followed by continued breastfeeding with complementary foods for up to 2 years. Breastfeeding has positive effects on the child's cognitive and emotional development as well as physical development.
questions.caregiver_note: Prolonged breastfeeding helps with the child's immunity and the formation of parent-child attachment.

questions.text: Are you aware that expressed breast milk can be stored at room temperature for up to 4 hours?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Education Needed
questions.actions: Expressed breast milk can be stored at room temperature (below 25°C) for up to 4 hours, in the refrigerator (4°C) for up to 3-4 days, and in the freezer (below -20°C) for 3-6 months. For long-term storage, use sealed dedicated plastic containers.
questions.caregiver_note: Temperature and container condition are important when storing breast milk, and thawed breast milk should not be refrozen. Stored milk should be warmed to near body temperature before use.

questions.text: Are you aware that in most cases, you do not need to stop breastfeeding even if the mother takes painkillers/antipyretics, cold medicine, or antibiotics?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No/Don't Know = Education Needed
questions.actions: Most medications used during breastfeeding are safe, and breastfeeding does not need to be stopped when taken under a doctor's prescription. If medication is necessary, space it out from breastfeeding or proceed after consulting a doctor.
questions.caregiver_note: Acetaminophen, ibuprofen, and penicillin antibiotics are classified as safe drugs during breastfeeding. Detailed information can be found on the NIH 'LactMed' database.

questions.text: How long did you exclusively breastfeed? (Refers to breastfeeding without using formula.)
questions.criteria: 6 months or more = Good, Less than 6 months = Education Needed
questions.actions: Ideally, exclusive breastfeeding should be maintained until 6 months of age according to national recommendations. After that, guide them to continue breastfeeding alongside solid foods.
questions.caregiver_note: Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended until 6 months, after which solid foods should be introduced to ensure balanced nutritional intake.

questions.text: Do you feed solid foods (complementary foods) three times a day?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Nutrition Guidance Needed
questions.actions: This is a transition period from soft porridge to foods with lumps like minced meat. Provide meals and snacks consistently 3 times a day (breakfast, lunch, dinner) to help form eating habits and balance nutritional supply.
questions.caregiver_note: Meals should include diverse food groups such as grains, vegetables, fruits, eggs, fish, and meat, and it is important to experience various textures to prevent picky eating.

questions.text: Does the solid food include grains, vegetables, fruits, eggs, fish, and meat?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Nutrition Supplementation Needed
questions.actions: Guide to ensure balanced intake of protein, iron, vitamins, and fiber through complementary foods containing all food groups. Caution is needed as deficiency in specific food groups (protein/iron sources, etc.) carries risks of growth retardation or anemia.
questions.caregiver_note: A diet including grains (rice, barley), vegetables (spinach, carrots), fruits (bananas, apples), and proteins (meat, eggs, fish) is desirable.

questions.text: Are you currently continuing breastfeeding?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Supplementation Guidance Needed
questions.actions: WHO and UNICEF recommend exclusive breastfeeding until 6 months, followed by continued breastfeeding alongside complementary foods until 2 years of age. Long-term breastfeeding has positive effects on immunity enhancement and cognitive development.
questions.caregiver_note: Continuing breastfeeding helps with the child's emotional stability and disease prevention.

questions.text: Are there any foods you specifically avoid or limit due to concerns about the child's allergies or asthma?
questions.criteria: Yes = Education Needed, No = Good
questions.actions: The AAAAI recommends introducing major allergenic foods (eggs, peanuts, nuts, fish, etc.) in small amounts starting from 4-6 months to help prevent allergies. Excessive restriction of specific foods can lead to nutritional deficiencies.
questions.caregiver_note: If there is no allergic reaction to a specific food, it is good to introduce various foods gradually. Guide to start with small amounts and stop immediately if an adverse reaction occurs.

questions.text: Are you aware that children should start eating on their own using a cup from 9 months?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Developmental Guidance Needed
questions.actions: After 9 months, children can attempt to hold a cup and drink alone. Cup usage helps with oral muscle development and hand coordination.
questions.caregiver_note: Let them practice little by little with a small cup at first, and encourage them even if they spill to foster autonomous eating habits.

questions.text: How long did you exclusively breastfeed? (Please enter the period you fed only breast milk without formula)
questions.criteria: 6 months or more = Good, Less than 6 months = Education Needed
questions.actions: Statistics on exclusive breastfeeding duration are used as basic data for future growth and nutritional development assessment. Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended until 6 months, followed by combination with solid foods.
questions.caregiver_note: Adjust the breastfeeding period flexibly according to the child's growth and development, but exclusive breastfeeding until 6 months is ideal.

questions.text: Do you think there is a problem with your child's eating habits?
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution, No = Good
questions.actions: Maintaining meal rhythm and rules is important during this period. Encourage the child to try eating alone, reduce distracting behaviors during meals, and maintain a consistent mealtime and space.
questions.caregiver_note: A child's eating habits are formed during the first 2 years of life. To prevent overeating and picky eating, it is good to establish a habit of eating at a designated seat with the family.

questions.text: Do you season the food your child eats?
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution Needed, No = Good
questions.actions: It is important to form eating habits that minimize salt intake during this period. Guide to limit intake of salty tastes, trans fats, and added sugars, and reduce the addition of salt and soy sauce during cooking.
questions.caregiver_note: Salty foods burden the infant's kidney function and can increase the risk of hypertension in adulthood. It is recommended to season lightly or add water to lower salinity during cooking.

questions.text: Does the child drink sweetened beverages or fruit juices?
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution Needed, No = Good
questions.actions: Sweet drinks (sodas, fruit juices, sugar-sweetened beverages) are high in calories but low in nutritional value, which can cause obesity and cavities. Water or unsweetened tea is recommended.
questions.caregiver_note: Excessive sugar intake can lead to reduced meal intake and nutritional imbalance. It is better to provide fruits and vegetables as snacks.

questions.text: Are you aware that whole grain consumption is beneficial for health?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Nutrition Guidance Needed
questions.actions: It is better to increase intake of whole grains rather than refined grains. Whole grains are rich in fiber, minerals, and B vitamins, helping prevent constipation and balance nutrition during growth.
questions.caregiver_note: Less polished brown rice, barley, and oats are rich in dietary fiber and good for the child's gut health. However, if digestion is difficult, mix with white rice initially.

questions.text: Do you give the child health supplements such as vitamins or minerals in addition to meals?
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution, No = Good
questions.actions: If a balanced diet is maintained, separate health supplements are not necessary. Supplementation of Vitamin D, Iron, etc., should be decided based on a doctor's prescription.
questions.caregiver_note: Overuse of health supplements can negatively affect liver function or growth development, so they should be taken after consulting a specialist.

questions.text: Do you think there is a problem with your child's eating habits?
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution, No = Good
questions.actions: After age 3, the habit of eating regularly with the family is important. Organize the dining environment so the child can focus, and limit snacks to 1 hour before/after meals.
questions.caregiver_note: Encouraging the child to prepare and participate in meals helps with autonomy and habit formation.

questions.text: Does the child eat three meals a day?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Caution
questions.actions: Three meals a day are essential for energy balance and growth development. To reduce picky eating, distinguish between meals and snacks.
questions.caregiver_note: Setting regular mealtimes develops the child's ability to regulate hunger and satiety.

questions.text: Are you aware that whole grain consumption is beneficial for health?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Education Needed
questions.actions: Less polished grains are rich in fiber and vitamins. Guide to increase the ratio of whole grains over refined grains.
questions.caregiver_note: Guide to increase the proportion of brown rice, barley, and oats over white rice to supplement dietary fiber.

questions.text: Does the child eat with the family every day?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Guidance Needed
questions.actions: Eating with the family allows the child to naturally learn healthy eating habits and social communication skills. Guide to eat at least one meal a day with the family if possible.
questions.caregiver_note: Family meals help with the child's emotional stability and improvement of eating habits. It is important for parents to demonstrate healthy eating habits.

questions.text: Does the child eat a lot of sweet foods?
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution, No = Good
questions.actions: Excessive sugar intake causes obesity, cavities, and nutritional imbalance. Provide fresh fruit and milk as snacks instead of sweet drinks and snacks.
questions.caregiver_note: Reducing sweet food intake naturally balances meal portions and diversifies food preferences.

questions.text: How long was the period you fed any amount of breast milk, or until what age? (Enter '0' if you did not breastfeed)
questions.actions: Statistical item

questions.text: Does the child eat three meals a day?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Caution
questions.actions: Educate to eat in a comfortable atmosphere at a consistent place (dining table). Ensure attention is not distracted by TV or play, and it is not desirable to force specific foods or use them as rewards. Provide 3 meals and snacks at regular times in a balanced way.
questions.caregiver_note: Regular eating habits are essential for nutritional balance and growth. It is good to create an environment where the family eats together.

questions.text: Does the child drink about two cups (500mL) of plain milk a day?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Nutrition Guidance Needed
questions.actions: Milk, a major source of calcium, is recommended at 400-600mL per day. Choose low-fat milk if overweight/obese, and caution is needed as excessive intake risks reduced appetite and anemia.
questions.caregiver_note: Milk helps with bone health in growing children, but excessive intake can hinder iron absorption. It is best to limit to within 2 cups a day.

questions.text: Are you aware that whole grain consumption is beneficial for health?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Education Needed
questions.actions: Whole grains are rich in dietary fiber, vitamins, and minerals, helping prevent constipation and nutritional balance. Guide to serve mixed brown rice, whole wheat, barley, etc., rather than white rice.
questions.caregiver_note: Gradually increasing the ratio of whole grains helps digestion adaptation and improves dietary diversity.

questions.text: Does the child avoid beverages with added sugar (soda, sports drinks, children's drinks, etc.) or fruit juices?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Caution
questions.actions: Beverages with strong sweetness can cause reduced meal intake, cavities, and obesity. Water or unsweetened beverages are recommended, and sugar-sweetened beverages should be limited to within 120-170mL per day.
questions.caregiver_note: Fruit juices contain high sugar content and more calories than actual fruit. It is preferable to replace them with water or milk.

questions.text: Do you tend to cook food with less salt for the child?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Caution
questions.actions: Educate to form eating habits that reduce salt intake. Based on the recommended daily sodium intake for adults (less than 2g), for children, this corresponds to 5g of salt (2g of sodium).
questions.caregiver_note: Becoming accustomed to salty tastes increases sodium intake, which can raise the risk of high blood pressure. It is good to season lightly or add water to lower salinity during cooking.

questions.text: Does the child have healthy eating habits?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Eating Habit Guidance Needed
questions.actions: A balanced diet is essential for the child's growth and weight gain. Guide to consume the 5 major food groups (grains, meat/fish/beans/eggs, vegetables, fruits, dairy) daily. If there are eating habit problems, identify specific causes like picky eating or irregular mealtimes and provide education.
questions.caregiver_note: Healthy eating habits directly affect the weight and height development of growing children. Please practice dietary diversification for a habit of eating evenly.

questions.text: Does the child prefer and frequently drink beverages or fruit juices instead of water?
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution, No = Good
questions.actions: Excessive juice or beverage consumption leads to excessive sugar intake, increasing the risk of obesity and cavities. Educate to drink water frequently instead of sweet drinks.
questions.caregiver_note: Juices have higher sugar content than actual fruit. It is good to form a habit of replacing them with water or unsweetened tea.

questions.text: Does the child consume dairy products (milk, plain yogurt, cheese, etc.) daily?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Nutrition Supplementation Needed
questions.actions: Dairy products are major sources of calcium and protein during growth. Intake of one cup (approx. 200mL) of milk, yogurt, or cheese per day is recommended.
questions.caregiver_note: Dairy products help with bone and tooth health. Encourage natural consumption as a dessert after meals.

questions.text: Does the child drink low-fat milk instead of regular milk?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Guidance Needed
questions.actions: Switching to low-fat milk is recommended after age 3. Low-fat milk provides sufficient protein and calcium while reducing calories and saturated fats.
questions.caregiver_note: Low-fat milk helps prevent obesity and has almost no nutritional loss compared to raw milk.

questions.text: Does the child consume various mixed grains, vegetables, and fruits daily?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Nutrition Supplementation Needed
questions.actions: Guide to consume diverse food groups daily. In particular, vegetables and fruits are important for immunity and digestive function maintenance, and it is good to provide foods of various colors evenly.
questions.caregiver_note: Encouraging the consumption of vegetables and fruits of 5 colors (red, yellow, green, white, purple) daily helps with nutritional balance.

questions.text: Does the child frequently eat sweet and salty foods, greasy instant foods, or fast food?
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution, No = Good
questions.actions: Fast food and processed foods are high in saturated fat and sodium, increasing the risk of obesity and chronic diseases. Educate to compose a diet centered on natural foods as much as possible.
questions.caregiver_note: Reduce intake of snacks, ice cream, hamburgers, pizza, etc., and correct eating habits to focus on home-cooked meals.

questions.text: Does the child spend more than 2 hours a day on TV, videos, smartphones, or games?
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution, No = Good
questions.actions: Educate to limit digital device use (screen time) to within 2 hours a day. Excessive screen exposure can affect sleep and attention.
questions.caregiver_note: It is desirable to increase outdoor play, physical activity, and reading time instead of smartphone or TV viewing.

questions.text: Does the child exercise to the point of sweating or running for more than 1 hour a day?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Activity Guidance Needed
questions.actions: Regular physical activity helps prevent obesity and develop muscles. Activities like walking, running, and cycling for more than 1 hour a day are recommended.
questions.caregiver_note: Exercise helps with physical health as well as concentration improvement. Please participate together to create a fun activity atmosphere.

questions.text: Does the child have healthy eating habits?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Eating Habit Guidance Needed
questions.actions: Guide to evenly consume the 5 major food groups (grains, meat/fish/beans/eggs, vegetables, fruits, dairy) to help growing children increase weight and height. If there are eating habit problems (picky eating, overeating, irregular mealtimes, etc.), identify the cause specifically and provide customized education.
questions.caregiver_note: Balanced meals are important for growth and immunity enhancement. Including food groups of various colors in meals helps with nutrient balance.

questions.text: Does the child eat breakfast every day?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Caution
questions.actions: Breakfast directly affects brain activity and learning concentration. Growing children need to consume sufficient energy and nutrition through regular breakfast.
questions.caregiver_note: Skipping breakfast increases the risk of obesity and pediatric vitamin deficiency. A balanced breakfast consisting of simple fruits, milk, eggs, etc., is recommended.

questions.text: Does the child prefer and frequently drink beverages or fruit juices instead of water?
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution, No = Good
questions.actions: Fruit juices and sugar-sweetened beverages are major causes of excessive sugar intake and increase the risk of obesity and cavities. Cultivate a water-drinking habit and limit beverages except for special occasions.
questions.caregiver_note: The habit of drinking water frequently instead of beverages helps maintain vitamin and mineral balance.

questions.text: Does the child consume dairy products (milk, plain yogurt, cheese, etc.) daily?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Nutrition Supplementation Needed
questions.actions: Dairy products are key for calcium supply during growth. Ensure regular consumption of one cup (approx. 200mL) of milk, yogurt, or cheese daily.
questions.caregiver_note: Dairy products are important for bone health and tooth growth. Providing them as snacks after meals naturally makes it a habit.

questions.text: Does the child drink low-fat milk instead of regular milk?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Caution
questions.actions: Switching to low-fat milk is recommended after age 3. Low-fat milk provides sufficient calcium and protein while reducing saturated fat intake.
questions.caregiver_note: Low-fat milk helps prevent obesity and has almost no nutritional loss. It is especially recommended for children with a tendency towards being overweight.

questions.text: Does the child consume various mixed grains, vegetables, and fruits daily?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Nutrition Supplementation Needed
questions.actions: Compose a diet considering the diversity and colors of vegetables and fruits. They are rich in dietary fiber and antioxidants, helping improve immunity and digestive function.
questions.caregiver_note: Consuming food groups of 5 colors (red, yellow, green, white, purple) daily helps maintain balanced nutrition.

questions.text: Does the child frequently eat sweet, salty, greasy instant foods or fast food as snacks or when eating out? (e.g., snacks, ice cream, hamburgers, pizza, etc.)
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution, No = Good
questions.actions: Fast food, fried foods, and processed foods are high in sodium, saturated fat, and sugars, which can harm the health of growing children. Snacks centered on natural foods (fruits, milk, boiled eggs, etc.) are recommended.
questions.caregiver_note: Please reduce instant food intake at home as well and practice a diet centered on fresh ingredients.

questions.text: Does the child spend more than 2 hours a day on TV, videos, smartphones, computers, or games for non-learning purposes?
questions.criteria: Yes = Caution, No = Good
questions.actions: Screen time should be limited to within 2 hours a day. Excessive media use can cause reduced attention, sleep disorders, and lack of exercise.
questions.caregiver_note: Media use exceeding 1-2 hours a day increases the risk of obesity. Please replace it with reading or outdoor activities.

questions.text: Does the child exercise to the point of sweating or run for more than 1 hour a day?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Activity Guidance Needed
questions.actions: Regular physical activity is essential for preventing obesity and developing muscles during growth. Activity of more than 1 hour daily, intense enough to cause sweating, is recommended.
questions.caregiver_note: Vigorous physical activity helps with immunity enhancement and stress relief. Parents participating together is more effective for forming exercise habits.

questions.text: Do you always use a car seat appropriate for the child's age and weight when traveling by car?
questions.actions: Please ensure you fully understand and follow the car seat educational materials.
questions.caregiver_note: Car seats are essential for safe travel starting from the newborn stage. They must be used even for short distances, and safety belts should always be checked.

questions.text: Do you always put the child down before performing actions such as answering the phone, drinking coffee, holding a bag, or picking up dropped objects while holding the child?
questions.actions: Performing other tasks while holding the child increases the risk of falls. Place the child in a safe location before proceeding with other actions.
questions.caregiver_note: Twisting or bending your body while holding the child can cause them to slip from your arms. Always place the child on a safe, flat surface first.

questions.text: Are you careful not to shake the child's head excessively when soothing them?
questions.actions: Excessive shaking can cause 'Shaken Baby Syndrome,' leading to cerebral hemorrhage, retinal hemorrhage, and neurological sequelae. Use methods like gently holding or singing to the child to soothe them.
questions.caregiver_note: Newborns have heavy heads and weak neck muscles, making them particularly vulnerable to excessive shaking.

questions.text: Has the child ever slept on an electric heating pad or heated water mat?
questions.actions: Prolonged exposure to heating devices can cause low-temperature burns. Since infants have immature thermoregulation, direct exposure to heat sources should be avoided.
questions.caregiver_note: Heated mats or electric pads may be warm for adults but can cause burns to babies.

questions.text: Do you always use a car seat appropriate for the child's age and weight when traveling by car?
questions.actions: Understand how to use the car seat and educate on the necessity of always being seated during vehicle travel.
questions.caregiver_note: Holding a child while traveling is dangerous in the event of an accident, even for short distances. A car seat must be used.

questions.text: Have you ever left the child alone on an adult bed or sofa, even for a moment?
questions.actions: Since the child can roll over during this period, do not leave them alone on beds or sofas.
questions.caregiver_note: Soft surfaces like beds or sofas pose a risk of suffocation and are a major cause of fall accidents.

questions.text: Are you aware of the problems associated with using a baby walker?
questions.actions: Walker use can cause injuries to the head, neck, arms, and legs, as well as fall accidents. Refrain from using them if possible, and allow plenty of time for crawling on the floor.
questions.caregiver_note: Walker use does not promote walking development and can be detrimental to balanced muscle development.

questions.text: Are you aware that shaking the child severely when soothing them is harmful?
questions.actions: Severe shaking can cause cerebral hemorrhage and retinal hemorrhage. Hold the child gently or sing to them.
questions.caregiver_note: 'Shaken Baby Syndrome' occurs most frequently in infants under 6 months of age.

questions.text: Have you ever left the child alone in a bath tub, basin, or bathroom, even for a moment?
questions.actions: Infants lack the reflex control for water, so drowning can occur in a very short time. Always observe them within arm's reach.
questions.caregiver_note: Suffocation/drowning can occur even in shallow water. Never leave the child alone.

questions.text: Have you ever consumed hot beverages while holding the child?
questions.actions: Do not drink hot beverages while holding the child as there is a risk of spilling.
questions.caregiver_note: Hot coffee or soup can cause severe burns to a child's skin.

questions.text: Has the child ever slept on an electric heating pad or heated water mat?
questions.actions: Heating devices can cause low-temperature burns due to the infant's lack of thermoregulation ability.
questions.caregiver_note: Do not use electric pads or heated mats for babies, whose body temperature rises easily.

questions.text: Are you aware of the risk of choking if the child plays with small objects that fit in their mouth, such as peanuts, corn kernels, grapes, buttons, or small toys?
questions.actions: The risk of choking is very high as children put everything in their mouths. Keep small objects out of reach and cut food into small pieces.
questions.caregiver_note: A child's airway is very narrow, so small objects pose a high risk of choking. Avoid beans, grapes, hard candies, and nuts before age 3.

questions.text: Are you aware that swallowing magnets or button batteries (coin cells) can cause dangerous complications such as intestinal perforation?
questions.actions: If a button battery is swallowed, visit the emergency room immediately. Esophageal perforation can occur within 30 minutes to 2 hours.
questions.caregiver_note: If symptoms like vomiting, drooling, or coughing appear after swallowing a battery, go to the hospital immediately. Lithium batteries, in particular, can cause severe damage due to chemical reactions.

questions.text: Do you ensure that electrical appliances, cords, and outlets with a risk of electric shock are out of the child's reach?
questions.actions: Install safety covers on outlets and organize cords after use.
questions.caregiver_note: Electric shock can lead to burns, muscle contractions, and cardiac arrest. Always manage electrical appliances out of the child's reach.

questions.text: Do you turn the handles of pots, pans, and skillets on the stove inward, away from the child's reach?
questions.actions: Always turn handles inward when cooking and place cooked food in the center of the table, out of reach. Keep hot water temperature below 50°C.
questions.caregiver_note: Hot liquids and cookware can cause severe burns to babies, so always be careful.

questions.text: Are there safety devices installed near stairs, windows, and verandas?
questions.actions: Install safety gates or locks on stairs and windows.
questions.caregiver_note: Prevention of fall accidents is important as the baby's range of movement expands.

questions.text: Is the child's bed placed away from windows or curtains?
questions.actions: Place the bed sufficiently away from walls or windows. Curtain cords or wires can cause strangulation accidents.
questions.caregiver_note: Keep the area around the bed clear and do not place objects the child can climb on.

questions.text: Have you ever left the child alone in a bath tub, basin, or bathroom, even for a moment?
questions.actions: Infants can drown in even 1-2 cm of water. Always observe them within arm's reach.
questions.caregiver_note: Never leave the child alone during a bath. Do not leave the spot even if the phone rings or the doorbell chimes.

questions.text: Do you use a car seat appropriate for the child's age and weight when traveling by car?
questions.actions: Understand car seat usage and guide the child to always be seated.
questions.caregiver_note: Car seats are essential during this period. In particular, keep the child seated in a rear-facing position.

questions.text: Do you store medicines, chemical products (bleach, detergents, etc.), and sharp objects out of the child's reach?
questions.actions: Store medicines, detergents, and chemical products in locked cabinets. Avoid cupboards or areas around the sink that the child can reach.
questions.caregiver_note: Children at this age develop the ability to open drawers and doors, so store chemicals on high shelves.

questions.text: Is the child's bed placed away from windows or curtains?
questions.actions: Arrange furniture away from windows and curtains, and keep chairs or sofas the child can climb on at a distance.
questions.caregiver_note: If furniture is placed near a window, the child may climb up and fall.

questions.text: Do you turn the handles of pots and pans on the stove inward, away from the child's reach?
questions.actions: Turn pot handles inward after cooking and do not place hot food on appliances.
questions.caregiver_note: Hot liquids or kettles can cause severe burns if tipped over.

questions.text: Have you ever left the child alone in a bath tub, basin, or bathroom?
questions.actions: Drowning can occur even in shallow water, so always ensure they play within the guardian's view.
questions.caregiver_note: Most drowning accidents in children occur within 1 minute, so never leave them alone.

questions.text: Do you use a car seat appropriate for the child's age and weight when traveling by car?
questions.actions: Select a car seat grade appropriate for the child's weight and install it in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.caregiver_note: Car seats are essential even after age 1. Adjust the backrest upright and ensure shoulder straps are level with the chest line.

questions.text: Have you ever left the child alone in a car?
questions.actions: Never leave the child alone in a vehicle. There is a risk of suffocation in enclosed spaces, especially in summer.
questions.caregiver_note: Leaving a child alone in a car, even for a moment, can lead to heatstroke, dehydration, and asphyxiation accidents.

questions.text: Have you installed safety devices such as safety gates or locks on stairs, windows, and verandas?
questions.actions: Secure windows and verandas so they do not open more than 10 cm.
questions.caregiver_note: This period is characterized by a high desire for exploration, leading to frequent fall accidents. Blocking access to windows is crucial.

questions.text: Have you ever left the child alone in a kiddie pool or bathtub?
questions.actions: Always allow water play within the guardian's view.
questions.caregiver_note: Motor skills have improved, but risk perception is still lacking. Never leave them alone.

questions.text: Do you store candles, lighters, electrical appliances, and cords out of the child's reach?
questions.actions: Unplug electrical appliances after use and store them in high places.
questions.caregiver_note: Access to electrical and fire devices must be blocked as curiosity creates strong impulses during this period.

questions.text: Does the child use a helmet and protective gear when riding a bicycle, inline skates, or scooter?
questions.actions: Instruct the child to strictly wear a helmet, knee pads, and elbow pads.
questions.caregiver_note: Safety gear is effective in preventing trauma by protecting the head and joints in case of falls.

questions.text: Does the child ever play on streets with vehicle traffic?
questions.actions: Educate the child to always walk with a guardian on roads.
questions.caregiver_note: A 4-year-old lacks situational judgment, so you must always hold hands while moving.

questions.text: Do you use a car seat or booster seat appropriate for the child's age and weight when traveling by car?
questions.actions: Review car seat educational materials and use a seat that fits the age-specific stage.
questions.caregiver_note: For weight under 15kg, use a 5-point harness car seat; thereafter, switch to a booster seat.

questions.text: Does the child always use a helmet and protective gear when riding a bicycle or inline skates?
questions.actions: Instruct the child to strictly wear a helmet when riding wheeled devices like bicycles or scooters.
questions.caregiver_note: Helmets prevent traumatic accidents by protecting the head during falls.

questions.text: Does the child ever play on streets with vehicle traffic?
questions.actions: Educate the child to always cross roads with a guardian.
questions.caregiver_note: Children under 10 years old need adult accompaniment when crossing roads.

questions.text: Do you use a car seat or booster seat appropriate for the child's age and weight when traveling by car?
questions.actions: Review car seat educational materials and strictly follow age-specific standards.
questions.caregiver_note: The most important protective device in a car accident is a car seat.

questions.text: Is the child aware of the rules to follow during water play?
questions.actions: Instruct the child to always be with a guardian during water play and not to approach deep water.
questions.caregiver_note: Clearly teach rules like no horseplay while swimming and no diving underwater.

questions.text: Do you store lighters, electrical appliances, and cords out of the child's reach?
questions.actions: Unplug electrical appliances after use and store fire sources in high places.
questions.caregiver_note: Repeated caution education is needed regarding electric shock and burn accidents.

questions.text: Do you store medicines or chemical products (bleach, cleaning agents, etc.) out of the child's reach?
questions.actions: Store medicines in locked cabinets and place detergents on high shelves, not under the sink.
questions.caregiver_note: A 5-year-old child can open doors independently, so locking devices are essential.

questions.text: Does the child always use a helmet and protective gear when riding a bicycle or inline skates?
questions.actions: Instruct the child to strictly wear a helmet and protective gear when riding wheeled devices like bicycles or inline skates. Repeatedly teach proper wearing methods and regularly check the condition of the gear.
questions.caregiver_note: Wearing protective gear prevents injuries to the head, knees, and elbows in case of falls. Safety equipment is only effective when worn correctly.

questions.text: Has the child ever crossed the street alone?
questions.actions: Teach the child never to cross a street with vehicle traffic alone. Always hold a guardian's hand and repeatedly educate on traffic light colors and how to use crosswalks.
questions.caregiver_note: Children under 10 have difficulty perceiving and judging traffic situations. Continuous guidance is needed to ensure the child does not cross the street alone.

questions.text: Do you strictly use a car seat or booster seat when traveling by car?
questions.actions: Review car seat educational materials and strictly use a booster seat appropriate for the child's weight and height.
questions.caregiver_note: Car seats are essential even after age 5. Children weighing less than 25kg must wear a booster seat.

questions.text: Does the child know the number to call in case of a fire?
questions.actions: Educate on how to call 119 (Emergency Services) and evacuation procedures in case of fire. Install smoke detectors at home, check them regularly, and repeatedly teach evacuation routes to the child.
questions.caregiver_note: Repeatedly teach the basic action: 'If there is a fire, call 119 and go outside.' It is recommended that parents practice so the child can say it or demonstrate it themselves.

questions.text: Have you ever let the child play alone at the playground?
questions.actions: Instruct the child to always stay within the guardian's view when playing at the playground. Teach them how to respond to strangers approaching and not to play alone or follow them.
questions.caregiver_note: Abduction and missing child incidents can happen in a split second. Always keep an eye on the child and repeatedly confirm the promise: 'Do not talk to strangers.'

questions.text: Do you put the baby to sleep on their stomach (prone) or side?
questions.actions: You must **always put the baby to sleep on their back (supine position)**. Sleeping on the stomach or side increases the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS). The head and neck must remain free to move during sleep.
questions.caregiver_note: Newborns have immature muscle control, so sleeping on the stomach or side can obstruct breathing. Sleeping on the back is the safest position.

questions.text: Do you sleep in the same bed as the baby?
questions.actions: Sharing a bed with parents increases the risk of suffocation or overlaying. The baby should sleep in a **separate crib or bassinet**, but within the parents' view.
questions.caregiver_note: While co-sleeping can help with attachment, it increases the risk of sleep-related accidents. Bed-sharing should be avoided especially if the guardian is overtired or taking medication.

questions.text: Do you cover the baby only up to the chest with bedding and use a swaddle?
questions.actions: Cover the baby only up to the chest to ensure the face remains uncovered. Remove loose blankets, pillows, and cushions.
questions.caregiver_note: Newborns have immature thermoregulation and are prone to overheating. Swaddling with a thin blanket is safe, whereas heavy comforters pose a suffocation risk.

questions.text: Do you place dolls, cushions, or bumper pads near the baby's sleep area, or let the baby sleep on soft bedding, car seats, or strollers?
questions.actions: Bumper pads, dolls, and cushions can cause suffocation. The baby should sleep on a firm, flat mattress.
questions.caregiver_note: The safest sleep environment is **clean and empty**. Car seats and strollers are not suitable for routine sleep.

questions.text: Do you continue breastfeeding while the baby is asleep?
questions.actions: Feeding during sleep can increase the risk of airway obstruction (choking). Burp the baby after feeding and try to feed when the baby is awake.
questions.caregiver_note: Breastfeeding reduces the risk of SIDS, but **feeding while sleeping can be dangerous due to a diminished swallowing reflex.**

questions.text: Are you aware that breastfeeding helps prevent Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS)?
questions.actions: Breastfeeding lowers the risk of SIDS. Continue breastfeeding if possible.
questions.caregiver_note: Studies show that breastfed infants have more stable autonomic control during sleep compared to non-breastfed infants.

questions.text: Do you follow a regular routine before bed, such as a bath, massage, lullaby, or storytelling?
questions.actions: A regular sleep routine promotes a sense of security and helps the baby sleep soundly. Avoid stimulating play before bed and create a quiet environment.
questions.caregiver_note: Sleep routines help establish the newborn's circadian rhythm and have a positive impact on long-term sleep habits.

questions.text: Does a smoker in the family or a guardian frequently come into contact with the child?
questions.actions: Smokers must wash their hands and change clothes before caring for the baby. Smoking indoors must be strictly prohibited.
questions.caregiver_note: Second-hand smoke is a major risk factor for SIDS. Residual nicotine particles (third-hand smoke) can remain on clothing, skin, and furniture, exposing the baby.

questions.text: Do you put the baby to sleep on their back?
questions.actions: You must always put the baby to sleep on their back. Sleeping on the stomach or side increases the risk of SIDS by more than 8 times.
questions.caregiver_note: Since physical control is still immature, sleeping on the back is the safest position.

questions.text: Do you place the baby on their side when awake to prevent flat head syndrome and aid development?
questions.actions: Time on the side or tummy is needed when awake for motor development and to prevent head deformation. However, the baby must be on their back during sleep.
questions.caregiver_note: Changing positions when awake helps with development and symmetry.

questions.text: Does the baby sleep in the same bed (bed, mattress) as the parents?
questions.actions: Sleeping in the same bed as parents poses a risk of compression or suffocation, so the baby should always sleep in a separate crib.
questions.caregiver_note: Keep the baby in the same room but in a separate bed so as not to obstruct the baby's breathing.

questions.text: Do you let the child fall asleep while nursing or holding a bottle, or while being rocked?
questions.actions: Nighttime feeding decreases around 6 months. Remove the bottle after the baby falls into a deep sleep and help them form the habit of falling asleep on their own.
questions.caregiver_note: Holding a bottle during sleep increases the risk of cavities and otitis media.

questions.text: Do you follow a regular routine before putting the baby to sleep, such as a bath, massage, lullaby, or reading?
questions.actions: Establish a consistent routine before bed so the child can predict sleep time.
questions.caregiver_note: Repetitive routines provide a sense of security and improve sleep quality.

questions.text: Do you nurse or give a bottle to put the baby back to sleep when they wake up?
questions.actions: Do not feed immediately when the baby wakes up at night; wait for them to fall back asleep on their own.
questions.caregiver_note: Self-soothing ability is directly linked to longer sleep duration later on.

questions.text: Around what time does the child fall asleep at night?
questions.actions: Bedtime before 9 PM is recommended. Late bedtime causes sleep deprivation and reduced concentration during the day.
questions.caregiver_note: Maintaining a consistent sleep schedule helps with growth hormone secretion and brain development.

questions.text: Does the child snore more than 3 days a week?
questions.actions: Habitual snoring can be a major symptom of Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA). If accompanied by frequent waking, daytime fatigue, or poor concentration, medical consultation is recommended.
questions.caregiver_note: Snoring is associated with growth retardation and learning difficulties.

questions.text: How many hours does the child sleep on average per day?
questions.actions: 10~13 hours of sleep per day is required. Sleep deprivation can cause hyperactivity, irritability, and weakened immunity.
questions.caregiver_note: Guide to keep naps short and maintain regular night sleep.

questions.text: Does the child have trouble sleeping or wake up frequently?
questions.actions: Frequent waking or severe snoring during sleep may indicate a sleep disorder. Consultation with a specialist is recommended if necessary.
questions.caregiver_note: Sleep problems can affect both growth and emotional development.

questions.text: Does the child express signals (facial expressions, posture, words, etc.) indicating the need to eliminate before doing so?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Guidance Needed
questions.actions: If the child shows specific behaviors or facial expressions before elimination, naturally encourage the use of the toilet. Do not force or scold; allow the child to form habits autonomously through successful experiences.
questions.caregiver_note: Recognizing and expressing the urge to eliminate is the first step in toilet training. Positive feedback is crucial for habit formation.

questions.text: Does the child attempt to remove their diaper and use the toilet during the day?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Guidance Needed
questions.actions: Attempt toilet use for certain periods during the day. Do not scold for failures, and provide ample praise for successes.
questions.caregiver_note: Children are typically ready to attempt using the toilet between 24 and 36 months. Coercive training can lead to toilet refusal.

questions.text: Can the child sleep through the night without a diaper?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Observation Needed
questions.actions: Nighttime bladder control is achieved later than daytime control. Do not scold the child for bedwetting, and reduce water intake before bedtime.
questions.caregiver_note: Nocturnal enuresis (bedwetting) can occur within the normal range up to age 5. It may temporarily increase due to stress or severe fatigue.

questions.text: Can the child go to the bathroom, eliminate, and wash their hands independently?
questions.criteria: Yes = Good, No = Lifestyle Guidance Needed
questions.actions: Place a step stool in the bathroom to allow the child to sit stably, and teach hand-washing habits after toileting.
questions.caregiver_note: It is important to teach hygiene habits alongside toileting. Practice procedures like hand washing and flushing as if they were a game.

questions.text: Has the child experienced straining during defecation or gone more than 3 days without a bowel movement?
questions.criteria: Yes = Detailed Evaluation Needed, No = Good
questions.actions: Persistent constipation can cause abdominal distension and loss of appetite. Increase fluid intake and maintain a fiber-rich diet.
questions.caregiver_note: Regular bowel movements are influenced by diet and physical activity. If defecation is painful, the child may withhold stool, so create a comfortable environment.

questions.text: Are there any abnormal findings in the eyeballs?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormal findings in the questionnaire and examination (marked sections) / Detailed Evaluation Needed: Any abnormal finding in even one item
questions.actions: If judged as 'Detailed Evaluation Needed', refer to an ophthalmologist early. Immediate evaluation is required if the shape of the eyeball is unclear, or if there is leukocoria (white pupil), severe congestion, or corneal opacity.
questions.pe_item:
1. Fixation and Following
2. External Eye Examination
3. Anterior Segment Examination using a Penlight
questions.pe_caution: The infant may not open their eyes during this period. Educate guardians on safe checking methods, as forced opening may damage the eyelids.

questions.text: Is there a family history of hereditary eye diseases (e.g., Retinoblastoma, Congenital Cataracts, Congenital Glaucoma)?
questions.criteria: Detailed Evaluation Needed if there is a family history of hereditary diseases.
questions.actions: Early evaluation is crucial if there is a family history. For congenital eye diseases, early detection determines the prognosis. Referral to ophthalmology is required.
questions.pe_item:
1. Fixation and Following
2. External Eye Examination
3. Anterior Segment Examination using a Penlight

questions.text: Does the child make good eye contact?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormal findings in the questionnaire and examination / Detailed Evaluation Needed: Any abnormal finding in even one item
questions.actions: Fixation and following are generally established before 6 months of age. If persistently immature, suspect refractive errors, strabismus, or amblyopia and refer to an ophthalmologist.
questions.pe_item:
1. Fixation and Following
2. External Eye Examination
3. Anterior Segment Examination using a Penlight

questions.text: Do the child's eyes turn inward (esotropia) or drift outward (exotropia) without focus?
questions.criteria: Detailed Evaluation Needed if there is continuous deviation inward or outward.
questions.actions: Strabismus persisting after 6 months requires early treatment. Possibility of congenital strabismus or refractive errors.
questions.pe_item:
1. Fixation and Following
2. External Eye Examination
3. Anterior Segment Examination using a Penlight

questions.text: Is the child's pupil (black center of the eye) cloudy?
questions.criteria: Detailed Evaluation Needed if there is pupil opacity or white reflex.
questions.actions: Leukocoria (white reflection in the pupil in photos) suggests congenital cataracts or retinal diseases (e.g., Retinoblastoma). Immediate referral to pediatric ophthalmology is required.
questions.pe_item:
1. Fixation and Following
2. External Eye Examination
3. Anterior Segment Examination using a Penlight

questions.text: Does the child make good eye contact?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormal findings in the questionnaire and examination / Detailed Evaluation Needed: Abnormal findings present
questions.actions: Fixation should be developmentally complete by this period. Poor fixation requires evaluation for refractive errors or amblyopia.
questions.pe_item:
1. Fixation and Following
2. External Eye Examination
3. Anterior Segment Examination using a Penlight
4. Red Reflex Test

questions.text: Do the child's eyes turn inward or drift outward without focus?
questions.criteria: Detailed Evaluation Needed if eye deviation persists.
questions.actions: Refer to ophthalmology if inward or outward strabismus persists. Early correction is critical for preventing amblyopia.
questions.pe_item:
1. Fixation and Following
2. External Eye Examination
3. Anterior Segment Examination using a Penlight
4. Red Reflex Test

questions.text: Is there a difference between the child's two pupils (size, color, light reflex)?
questions.criteria: Detailed Evaluation Needed if there is a difference in pupil size (anisocoria), color, or red reflex.
questions.actions: Differentiate congenital cataracts or retinoblastoma in case of pupil difference or white reflex. Immediate ophthalmology referral.
questions.pe_item:
1. Fixation and Following
2. External Eye Examination
3. Anterior Segment Examination using a Penlight
4. Red Reflex Test

questions.text: Does the child have difficulty making eye contact, or do the eyes shake/tremble (nystagmus)?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormal findings in the questionnaire and examination / Detailed Evaluation Needed: Any abnormal finding in even one item
questions.actions: Nystagmus (eye shaking) may be associated with congenital conditions or delayed visual development. Early ophthalmological evaluation is recommended.
questions.pe_item:
1. Fixation and Following
2. External Eye Examination
3. Anterior Segment Examination using a Penlight
4. Red Reflex Test
5. Ocular Motility (Strabismus) Test

questions.text: Does the child consistently turn their face to the side or tilt their head when looking at objects in front?
questions.criteria: Detailed Evaluation Needed if forward fixation is poor or specific head posture is maintained.
questions.actions: Suspect strabismus, oblique muscle dysfunction, or refractive errors. Early evaluation is needed if the behavior is repetitive.
questions.pe_item:
1. Fixation and Following
2. External Eye Examination
3. Anterior Segment Examination using a Penlight
4. Red Reflex Test
5. Ocular Motility (Strabismus) Test

questions.text: Does the child get too close to books, TV, or objects, or squint when looking at them?
questions.criteria: Detailed Evaluation Needed if focus is only at close range or squinting persists.
questions.actions: Possible refractive errors such as myopia or astigmatism. Ophthalmology consultation is needed if the behavior repeats.
questions.pe_item:
1. Fixation and Following
2. External Eye Examination
3. Anterior Segment Examination using a Penlight

5. Ocular Motility (Strabismus) Test

questions.text: Do the child's eyes occasionally turn inward or outward?
questions.criteria: Detailed Evaluation Needed if intermittent strabismus is suspected.
questions.actions: Possibility of strabismus or amblyopia. Early treatment is needed if it persists.

1. Fixation and Following

questions.criteria: Detailed Evaluation Needed if forward fixation is poor or specific posture is maintained.
questions.actions: Possibility of strabismus, oblique muscle issues, myopia, or astigmatism. Early ophthalmological evaluation if persistent.
questions.pe_item:
1. Fixation and Following

questions.text: Does the child get too close to books, TV, or objects, or squint when looking at them?
questions.criteria: Detailed Evaluation Needed if close-range focus or squinting persists.
questions.actions: Possibility of refractive errors (myopia, astigmatism). Eye exam required if repetitive.

questions.text: Do you feel there is a difference in vision between the two eyes when covering one eye?
questions.criteria: Detailed Evaluation Needed if binocular vision difference is suspected.
questions.actions: Suspect amblyopia or anisometropia. Immediate referral to ophthalmology.
questions.pe_item:
1. Fixation and Following
2. External Eye Examination
3. Anterior Segment Examination using a Penlight
4. Red Reflex Test
5. Ocular Motility (Strabismus) Test

questions.text: Does the child consistently turn their face to the side or tilt their head when looking at objects in front?
questions.criteria: Detailed Evaluation Needed if there is a preference for one visual field.
questions.actions: Possibility of strabismus, myopia, or astigmatism. Visual acuity test and ophthalmology visit recommended if persistent.
questions.pe_item: Visual Acuity Test

questions.text: Does the child get too close to books, TV, or objects, or squint when looking at them?
questions.criteria: Detailed Evaluation Needed if close-range focus or squinting persists.
questions.actions: Possibility of refractive errors. Prescription glasses recommended if necessary after vision test.
questions.pe_item: Visual Acuity Test

questions.text: Do the child's eyes occasionally turn inward or outward?
questions.criteria: Detailed Evaluation Needed if intermittent strabismus is suspected.
questions.actions: Possibility of accommodative esotropia or intermittent exotropia. Strabismus test needed.
questions.pe_item: Visual Acuity Test

questions.text: Do the child's eyes occasionally look blank or unfocused?
questions.criteria: Good: No abnormality / Detailed Evaluation: Any abnormality present
questions.actions: Visual acuity test needed if intermittent strabismus or amblyopia is suspected.
questions.pe_item: Visual Acuity Test

questions.text: Have you ever visited an ophthalmologist upon recommendation from an infant health checkup?
questions.criteria: Re-verification of screening abnormalities required.
questions.actions: Re-evaluation needed if there were past screening abnormalities. Refer to ophthalmology if symptoms persist.
questions.pe_item: Visual Acuity Test
